content.definition: A surgical technique involving the suture of a patch of autologous or prosthetic material to an arteriotomy site to widen the lumen and prevent stenosis at the closure site. Most commonly used in carotid endarterectomy, femoral endarterectomy, and arterial repairs.
indications: Small caliber arteries at risk for stenosis with primary closure
Traumatic arterial repair when primary repair would narrow lumen

patch_sizing: Cut patch to appropriate width (usually 8-10 mm for carotid)
Taper ends to avoid dog ears
Length to cover entire arteriotomy plus margin
suturing: Start at one apex with locking suture
Alternatively: start at both apices, meet in middle
completion: Release clamps in sequence (internal carotid last for CEA)

learning_objectives: Compare autologous vs prosthetic patch materials
clinical_pearls: Patch closure is STANDARD OF CARE for CEA
Vein patch: excellent but rare aneurysm risk; bovine pericardium: good alternative
Patch width ~8-10 mm for carotid; taper ends to prevent dog-ears
Always backbleed before completing patch closure
